name: upshift
content:
upshift verb [I]
(WAY OF LIVING)
Add to word list
Add to word list
UK to spend more time working and earning money, or to get a job that is better paid and more difficult: You may eye the wealth and success of your former workmates and yearn to upshift again.
More examplesFewer examplesAbout 41,000 people will downshift, but the number of people choosing to upshift will be roughly the same.These young people haven't upshifted enough to be able to downshift.Downshifters want to slow down at work so that they can upshift in other areas of their lives.

upshift verb [I]
(INCREASE)
to increase in amount or speed: Home ownership has upshifted substantially in response to improvements in the economy. Over the course of the summer, the show upshifted from its already robust sales.
More examplesFewer examplesConsumer prices rose 0.4% in November, upshifting from a 0.1% increase in October.If you believe that oil prices have upshifted structurally, the outlook is fairly positive.

upshift verb [I]
(VEHICLE)
US to change to a higher gear when driving, to increase power and speed: Every time you upshift, the rear wheel spins. Just trying to upshift and downshift was tricky.
More examplesFewer examplesThe transmission does not automatically upshift.The manufacturer has identified a potential fault when riders upshift from first to second gear.I lazily upshifted early in a roundabout and the motorcycle lurched.
